moves.1. e4 c5 2. f4: we have to pick a bone with this: the Grand Prix Attack...
moves.2... Nc6: taking a different approach, than straight Hungarian...
moves.3. Nf3 d6: not consistent with this opening: only d6, after Nc3...
moves.6... Be7 7. Be3: so we can play this important move...
moves.11. O-O Rac8: a bit of a standard move: White could not be bothered...
moves.15. Bf3 Ng7 16. Ng4: this is, why we call this the Grand Prix Attack: White gained a lot of space and play...
moves.16... f5: forcing the issue: never wait out a full threat...
moves.17. Nh6+ Kh8 18. exf5 exf5 19. Bd5 Bd8: forced: square f7 is suddenly an issue...
moves.20. Nf7+: better serve this threat out, right away...
not good: Black is trying to force his way into Whites' position...
replacing the King: Bb7 is a dangerous piece...
moves.27... Bb6 28. Nh4 Na5 29. Rh2 Re8 30. b4: probably better than cxb4, cxb4, Nc6...
moves.31... a6 32. a5 Ba7 33. c4 bxc4 34. dxc4: an oops moment: Qxd6+ was not foreseen...
moves.35... Re6: trying to put out a fire with gasoline...
moves.38. Bxf4 Nxf4 39. Kf3 Re4: Qd6+ will just not work: we need a big persuasion...
